body:
https://github.com/StatusPage/sidekiq/commit/017f0a2ef11da195bf30d9c3e29cb48816505065

I'm pretty naive for how everyone spawns/closes their worker processes, so I figured I'd propose this to get feedback before writing tests and doing documentation. This works for me in a sample app, with the callbacks blocking as you would expect. In our case, we need to flush the Librato agent right before quit.

Seems legit.
1. I'd add error handling around the callback. 
2. try is an ActiveSupport extension so Sidekiq can't use it.
Open up a real PR and we can discuss in more detail.

issue.title: Shutdown Hooks

repository.name: sidekiq
repository.description: Simple, efficient background processing for Ruby

issue.body: Is there a clean way to add shutdown hooks to to Sidekiq? For instance, one may want to close some persistent TCP connections or close a file that Sidekiq is writing to.

body: @scootklein Any chance for a PR soon or do you want me to reimplement this?

i’ll get you something tonight

## 

sbk

On Sunday, March 9, 2014 at 10:12 AM, Mike Perham wrote:

> @scootklein (https://github.com/scootklein) Any chance for a PR soon or do you want me to reimplement this?
>

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub (https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq/issues/1534#issuecomment-37130610).

repository.name: sidekiq
repository.description: Simple, efficient background processing for Ruby

body: This appears to be at the process level, is there a way to hook into individual worker threads shutdown?

Nope. What are you trying to do?

> On Oct 31, 2018, at 06:47, Olivier Lacan <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> This appears to be at the process level, is there a way to hook into individual worker threads shutdown?
>

> You are receiving this because you modified the open/close state.
